title: 114_hr5330
content: The "Peer-Support Specialist Act of 2016" requires a report on best practices for peer-support specialist programs, training, and certification. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report on best practices and standards for peer-support specialist programs within 2 years of the Act's enactment. A peer-support specialist is defined as an individual who uses their personal recovery experience to help others with mental illness or substance use disorders. A peer-support specialist uses personal recovery experience to assist individuals with mental illness or substance use disorders by providing non-medical services within their scope of practice. They facilitate support groups and work one-on-one with clients, meeting criteria set by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The report under this subsection will include information on best practices and standards for defining a peer-support specialist, including hours of experience, types of specialists, exams required, code of ethics, and additional training in various areas. The requirements for completing documentation activities include explaining what, where, when, and how. Required skill sets include knowledge of risk indicators, de-escalation techniques, suicide prevention, trauma response, stages of change, and accessing mental health services. Requirements for continuing education include effectively working in care teams, facilitating service coordination, and supporting individuals in meeting recovery goals. The Peer Professional Workforce Development Grant Program is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of Health and Human Services awards grants to develop behavioral health paraprofessional training programs to increase the number of trained peers, recovery coaches, and addiction specialists. Eligible entities include community colleges and training programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services awards grants to develop behavioral health paraprofessional training programs. Grants aim for national geographic distribution and may prioritize programs for youth aged 16 to 25. $10,000,000 is authorized annually from 2017 to 2021 for this purpose.
